reviews.text: We were traveling with friends of ours, altogether a party of 6. We were able to all fit in the Canyon Loft cabin, and so the price worked out pretty reasonably per family.
reviews.title: Camping light at a premium price

reviews.text: It was unusually hot on the 2nd night we stayed there, and there was a thermal inversion effect happening within the canyon. NO breeze to speak of, and unbearably hot. They did provide a plug-in fan, but sleeping in the loft was pretty difficult regardless. I would definitely not come here if hot weather was expected. Also, the creek bed was dry this time of year and it would have been so much nicer/lush if we had come in winter/spring.
reviews.title: Nice, but location is key, esp. for the price you pay

reviews.text: But that aside, the firepit was awesome and the stars were amazing. The nearby beach was fun and not crowded at all. We even saw dolphins swimming just off the coast.
reviews.title: Glamping it up

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: El Capitan Canyon really isn't near anything--closest town is about 20 min away. So most of the time, you eat the food you brought or or you eat at the on-site grocery store/restaurant. I would DEFINITELY try to bring as much of your own food/beverage as possible. While breakfast is pretty reasonable, the BBQ and S'mores kits are super premium priced and you will dine better if you just plan ahead and bring your own supplies.
reviews.title: Too expenisive!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I like camping but just can't sleep in a tent/ground any more, so this is the best of both worlds. Having stayed here several years before, I kind of knew what to expect: grounds/cabins are nice, depending on the section; kitchenette & micro; clean bathroom/shower; small creek; flies (in swarms); tweens running around unsupervised.
reviews.title: Lord of the Flies Campground

likes.liked: — There were some trees around to muffle some of the noise.
likes.disliked: — Seriously, the kids. Don't advertise this as a romantic getaway spot.

reviews.text: I loved the Sunset photos of El Capitan and am completely bought into the concept of glamping, but found this spot to be poorly run and expensive for what it is. We've stayed several times at Maho Bay on St. Johns and found that to be an incredible spot and a great value. The idea is a fine one and the cabins are cute, but they are breathtakingly close together in spots. The "creek" is so overgrown that you barely know it is there, a little selective pruning would go a long way!
reviews.title: Expensive for what you get

likes.liked: — The cabins were cute looking and the location is pretty.
likes.disliked: — The communal bathrooms were dirty and the cabins were very poorly lit and everything was expensive.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We walked in with no reservation on a Saturday in November and they were unwilling to cut us any sort of deal, even though they clearly had lots of open cabins. Because we were vacationing on the cheap we rented the cabin with 4 bunk beds, but even that came to $254, which seemed like a lot for a Saturday night in November in essentially the middle of nowhere.
reviews.title: Like sleeping in a picnic playground

likes.disliked: — Constant screaming kids and urban playground feel to the environment

reviews.text: The most difficult part to fathom was that the check in staff and the other staff we encountered were totally clueless about their surroundings. They couldn't tell us about the trails on the property, the trees next to the check in house, nor were they "aware" that you can hear the highway from the lower section of cabins. An eco friendly resort where none of the staff likes the environment enough to know anything about it?
reviews.title: Not What I Expect

likes.liked: — Fire pits. Down pillows and comforters
likes.disliked: — Cabins and tents are located too close to each other

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Overall, it seemed like a good idea that was very poorly executed. That said, we saw lots of families with kids having a great time. We had a good time, did a beautiful hike up in the hills and drove down to the beach close by. The food in the cantina was good for breakfast, we ate dinner elsewhere. Overall, if I lived close by and was unfazed by cost I might come back here and rent their largest cabin with my family. As it is, I do care about cost and value and we won't be back.
reviews.title: Know before you go

likes.liked: — The cabin was cute, staff was friendly

reviews.text: We stayed for 2 nights and we were expecting some kind of wilderness canyon. It is not like that at all! Instead of trying to paint a picture of a camping image, to be truthful the brochure should show a picnic area with playgrounds and swings, with kids screaming all day and night, with the cabins and tents right next to each other. Just imagine a crowded suburban public park on a holiday. Late at night we could hear the faint thunder of the trucks rolling down the 101 freeway in the distance (not very loud but it is unmistakeable that this is NOT a real nature experience). This place is very close to the freeway. On the plus side, the common shower facilities were very clean. If you stay here expecting a wilderness camping experience you will be disappointed. However if go in with the mindset that it's more like a sleep-over in a playground park environment, then you will have realistic expectations. Neat business idea, but this is not what I would call camping.
reviews.title: Pleasant weekend for grown-ups; Great for children

likes.liked: — Bathroom inside the cabin, easy access to pool and market, beautiful surroundings
likes.disliked: — far from car parking, a bit pricey

reviews.title: Relaxing - camping with luxuries
reviews.text: My husband and I planned a quick anniversary trip and stayed September 29-October 1. My husband always wants to camp, I do not, and this is the closest I am likely to get to it. The goal for the trip was purely to get away from everything.

We booked the wine package - creekside king cabin (came with bottle of wine plus a s'mores kit). From the moment we pulled in and were guided to our cabin, through the moment we checked out, everyone was extremely friendly and professional. Our cabin was at the very far end of the park which made it a nice, brisk walk to the kitchen and entry gate. We were two of very few guests on our first evening and a school group appeared on our second night (they were nice high school kids, only saw them at the pool, no bother, and never heard them). With that said, I can't imagine how the canyon would be in Summer - not a romantic place for adults but probably a great place for families that know each other (cabins are close). Our cabin was adorable - extremely comfortable bed, cozy linens, clean bathroom (although tub seemed to flood everywhere when using shower, not a big problem - just a heads up to the property managers), great kitchen (fyi - they stock with dishwashing liquid, coffee pot, and microwave). We loved cooking out at night and the ability to drive to Santa Barbara for dinner as well.
reviews.title: Totally overpriced

reviews.text: Yes, in hindsight, El Capitan Canyon is a bit pricey. However, it is in Santa Barbara County which is very pricey. It was fairly close to the same price we would have spent for the same two nights at Bacara, but El Capitan presents a totally different experience. If you want to give camping a shot but have the luxuries of a comfortable bed, give this a try. Again, I can't say enough about the great staff working at El Capitan. Everyone we came across helpful, pleasant, and made us feel very comfortable in an unpretentious way. Oh, we loved the cat at the front desk - too cute (and I am far from a cat lover).
reviews.title: High End Camping

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We, a family with three kids (14,12,6) stayed here for two nights. The location is great, the campground clean. Our canyon loft cabin was at the far upper end of the property, about 1 mile away from the check-in and market. We needed the car all the time to drive up and down. I have no idea how that works in summer, when there are more people and the no-car-policy will be more enforced. $350 for a night was simply 150-200 bucks too much. Sure, the cabin was nice, the location and view as well. But the loft, where the three kids slept on some simple mattresses was not more then 3 or 4 feet high - very basic accommodation.
reviews.title: They don't care if your uncomfortable, that no one respects their policy of absolutely no amplified music, which is what

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Oh, read the directions carefully when you plan to come. Our navigation system in the car does not know the "officical" address 11560 Calle Real, Santa Barbara. The correct address (for our system) was 11560 Calle Real, Goleta, CA. There is no sign at the freeway although the property is right next to it.
reviews.title: YMCA Camp for Kids

reviews.text: We stayed at El Capitan Canyon Sun-Tues and we had a fantastic time! Our cabin was located in the Lower Loop, which is the area that is closest to the market. After taking a walk to the other areas, I believe this was the best area (we stayed in cabin 110). There was a large grassy area is the center of the loop which made it perfect for our 12 month old's playtime. The food from the market was delicious, especially the pancakes, omlettes, cinnamon rolls, coffee and sandwiches. Everything was served piping hot and quickly.
reviews.title: Glamping at its finest!

reviews.text: The cabin was very nice and clean. There was plenty of room for all of our gear, including a pack n' play. There was a microwave, sink and mini-fridge. The bathroom was the best part! Although small, the shower was hot. The extra money for the cabin was well worth it....we didin't have to use the community shower and toilets!
reviews.title: Totally Fun!!!
Had a fun time.
reviews.text: The only down side to our stay (and it was a very minor one in the grand scheme of things) were the wasps/bees. They were everywhere and unafraid of citronella candles. Contrary to popular belief, they WILL sting you (my brother-in-law was stung on the leg by one). Wasps/bees retreat at sundown, which makes it a perfect time to cook/eat outside. Next time, we will only bring food for dinner and have breakfast and lunch at the market.

There are plenty of hiking trails available (we didn't take any because we had the baby). We did, however, take a walk across to El Capitan State Beach (about 15 minute walk) which was very nice. We are already planning our next trip!
reviews.title: Last minute change stressful

reviews.text: We planned this trip very last minute and didn't book our cabin until the night before. Originally 3 friends and I had planned on going to Catalina to get away from the city (LA) for a couple days. After realizing that it might be more work than we had time to plan for, we decided to head to Santa Barbara instead. We did a little research and came across the El Capitan Cabins. We booked the cabin with the bunkbeds and had a blast. We brought our own food to cook over an open fire- smores and all and wine to last us the whole night.
reviews.title: It all depends on your expectation
